Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story:
I stared at my phone during lunch break, the screen lighting up with a string of messages from my stepdad. He wanted to know how my day was going, if I’d eaten, if I was feeling okay. Ever since I moved in, he and Mom expected me to check in, to share the little details of my life. It was their way of making me feel part of the family, and I tried to keep up, replying quickly, sending photos, even when I was tired.

But at the site, things were different. The foreman had just posted a notice about an optional training session next week. He said it was a good chance to learn new skills, maybe even get considered for more responsibility. The guys were already talking about who’d go, and I knew showing up would mean I was serious about the job. But the session was in the evening, right when my family expected me home for dinner and our usual catch-up. I could already imagine the disappointment in my stepdad’s voice if I told him I’d be late, or worse, if I didn’t answer his messages at all. My phone buzzed again, and I felt the pressure building, torn between being the son they wanted and the worker I needed to be.
